title: Kate Roetcisoender
text: Kate Roetcisoender is a marine science student at Cal State Monterey Bay, minoring in statistics.

title: Kate Roetcisoender
text:
Education
California State University, Monterey Bay | Seaside, CA
B.S. in Marine Science, Minor in Statistics | 2020 - 2025

title: Kate Roetcisoender
text:
Experience
Department of Marine Science | Undergraduate Research Assistant | May 2022 - present
Moss Landing Marine Laboratories | Laboratory Technitian | August 2024 - January 2025

title: About
text:
Kate Roetcisoender
I am an undergraduate student at Cal State University, Monterey Bay majoring in marine science and minoring in statistics, and graduating in Spring 2025. I have worked in Dr. James Lindholm’s Image Analysis and Fish Ecology Lab for almost three years and have extensive experience in the field, analyzing video, and data processing.   I grew up in the Mojave desert with few visits to the ocean, but still managed to find my passion for marine science. I have since moved to Monterey, California, where I get to see the ocean everyday, as well as work towards long-term monitoring solutions to understand the health of fish communities worldwide. I have been working on an independent project under Dr. James Lindholm analyzing the relative merits of various forms of video data collection, with the hopes of submitting for publication shortly after graduation. Additionally, I have been assisting in the virtual reality (VR) diving program, which has allowed me to participate in bringing underwater footage to high school classrooms to teach about marine science, marine protected areas, and research diving. Through all of these experiences, I have fallen further in love with marine science and the ocean, and plan to pursue making a difference for the rest of my life.

title: portfolio-part-1
text:
1. Identify your data source.
These data come from sampling efforts that I participated in over the summer of 2023 for a marine protected area effectiveness evaluation through the Lindholm imagery analysis lab.
2. Describe your data, including variables and data types.
Drop_ID - sample (drop) identifier
Date - YYYYMMDD, when the video was taken
Location - the marine protected area that was sampled
Designation - whether the video was taken inside the MPA or outside (REF)
3D Points - number of fish counted in drop
3D Lengths - number of fish measured in drop
Depth (m) - depth of drop in meters
Habitat - Hard = all rock, mixed-hard = mostly rock, mixed-soft = mostly sand/mud, soft = all sand/mud
Relief - High = >2 meters depth change, Medium = 1-2 meter, Low = <1 meter
Rugosity - The complexity (holes, cracks, overhangs, etc.) of the habitat
Simpson_div - Gini-Simpson diversity index
Shannon_div - Shannon-Wiener diversity index
3. Identify the research questions you want to answer.
How does species diversity vary inside and outside of marine protected areas?
How does relative abundance and size vary inside and out of MPAs?
How does habitat vary inside and out of MPAs?

title: portfolio-part-1
text:
1. Identify your data source.
These data come from sampling efforts that I participated in over the summer of 2023 for a marine protected area effectiveness evaluation through the Lindholm imagery analysis lab.
2. Describe your data, including variables and data types.
Drop_ID - sample (drop) identifier
Date - YYYYMMDD, when the video was taken
Location - the marine protected area that was sampled
Designation - whether the video was taken inside the MPA or outside (REF)
3D Points - number of fish counted in drop
3D Lengths - number of fish measured in drop
Depth (m) - depth of drop in meters
Habitat - Hard = all rock, mixed-hard = mostly rock, mixed-soft = mostly sand/mud, soft = all sand/mud
Relief - High = >2 meters depth change, Medium = 1-2 meter, Low = <1 meter
Rugosity - The complexity (holes, cracks, overhangs, etc.) of the habitat
Simpson_div - Gini-Simpson diversity index
Shannon_div - Shannon-Wiener diversity index
3. Identify the research questions you want to answer.
How does species diversity vary inside and outside of marine protected areas?
How does relative abundance and size vary inside and out of MPAs?
How does habitat vary inside and out of MPAs?

title: portfolio-part-1
text:
Data Visualization
1. What do you want your final visualizations to look like?
How does species diversity vary inside and outside of marine protected areas?

Boxplot of diversity by designation with all locations included, then faceted by location.

How does relative abundance and size vary inside and out of MPAs?

Bar chart of average abundances by designation
Ridgeplot of sizes by designation, with vertical lines showing where the mean or median is.

How does habitat vary inside and out of MPAs?

Bar plots comparing habitat metrics by designation, faceted by location.

2. What do you want to highlight on your final visualizations in order to answer your research questions? How do you plan to do that?

I want to highlight potential differences, if any, between inside and outside of marine protected areas. I plan on doing that with lines, annotations, and captions.

3. What is missing from your data or would need to change in your data to create these visualizations?

I need to get the average fish sizes by drop, which I will do by summarizing another data set and joining it to the main one I will be using (more details below).

title: portfolio-part-1
text:
Data Cleaning
1. Do you need to reformat any variables into different types (e.g. factors, time, dates, strings)? Or remove information from variable values?
Yes, OpCode will need to be reclassified as categorical, not numeric.
2. Do you need to deal with any missing data, especially missing data coded other than NA?
There are some missing values for habitat, relief, and rugosity. These are already coded as NA.
3. Do you need to filter your data? How?
No
4. Do you need to create any new variables? What variables? How?
Yes, I would like to create a species richness variable by grouping by drop then counting the unique species, then joining that table to the drop data. I would also like to create an average fish length variable by grouping by drop then calculating the mean of lengths and joining that to the drop data.
5. Do you need to add new data (join) to your data? What data? How?
See above question. The data added comes from the same sampling effort, but looks at individual fish instead of the overall drop.
6. Are there any variables you can exclude from your data?
Yes, date and one of the diversity indices can be excluded.
7. Do you need pivot your data in any way? Why? How?
No.
8. Do you need to summarize any of the variables? Which ones? How?
See question 4.
9. What other aspects of your data need to be “fixed” in order to make your data visualizations?
None (hopefully).

title: An exploration of fish communities in California MPAs
text:
Data Description
These datasets are from a summer of data collected in 2023, with the purpose of assessing the possible impacts of marine protected areas (MPAs) on the fish communities they protect. That summer, the Lindholm lab and I completed four week long data collection trips at four different MPAs along California’s central and north coast. We deployed stereo camera systems for 45 minutes each, then took that video back to the lab and spent the fall collecting fish data from it. Stereo video specifically uses two cameras to triangulate objects where the frames overlap, allowing us to measure fish down to the millimeter without ever touching them. These data were eventually processed and submitted to inform MPA management.
Here is the data: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1KVd_7IsOHM9Xe1PDIf47Q4LnQt4J6QFjS5UL1i_GzpA/edit?gid=0#gid=0
Sheets:

Drop_data - information on each camera system deployment 
3D_points - Each individual fish counted 
Lengths - The precise measurement of each fish able to be measured

Variables of interest:

OpCode OR Drop_ID - sample (drop) identifier 
Date - YYYYMMDD, when the video was taken 
Location - the marine protected area that was sampled 
Designation - whether the video was taken inside the MPA or outside (REF) 
3D Points - number of fish counted in drop 
3D Lengths - number of fish measured in drop 
Depth (m) - depth of drop in meters 
Simpson_div - Gini-Simpson diversity index 
Shannon_div - Shannon-Wiener diversity index 
Common_name - common name of each species of fish



Data Cleaning
For the first visualization, I started with the 3D_points data and pulled out just the columns of OpCode and Common_name. Then, grouping by OpCode, I counted the number of unique values for Common_name. This is calculating the number of different species seen per sample, or species richness. I then take this information and add it to the Drop_data sheet. I then make minor changes such as renaming the species richness variable and ordering the locations from south to north before making the visualization.  For the second visualization, I used the lengths sheet, and pulled out columns Date, Location, Designation, Length (mm), OpCode, and Common_name. I then removed observations of Northern Anchovies. This was a pretty extreme outlier, where in one video, a bait ball of thousands of anchovies swam in view of the cameras. This was severely skewing the data, and only happened in one out of over 200 drops, so it was removed. Then I converted the lengths from millimeters to centimeters and ordered the locations from south to north before making the second visualization.


Figure 1
Point Lobos has the highest species richness (number of different species), and Montara has the lowest. We would expect that the species richness decreases as we move northward, however, Point Lobos is the oldest State Marine Reserve (no take) in California, likely causing it to have higher richness than the more south Point Buchon. In all but Ano Nuevo, the MPA appears to have higher species richness than the reference site. Ano Nuevo may be an exception to this because it is a hard to access and poorly enforced MPA, likely causing there to be no difference inside and out of the MPA. The strongest difference is in Point Lobos, again likely due to it being the oldest no take zone in California.





Figure 1: Species richness is generally higher in MPAs than reference sites






Figure 2
Ano Nuevo appears to have the largest proportion of large fish. Point Buchon and Point Lobos have a large density of small fish, which are mostly young of the year rockfish, Suggesting these sites serve as nurseries. There is also a higher density as the graph moves from north to south. At our north most sites, there was a lot more sand and mud, as opposed to rocky habitat, so we saw less fish, as most fish like to aggregate over rocky substrate. Additionally, Ano Nuevo did not have many samples due to poor weather, leading to even fewer fish observations. Montara had a lower proportion of large fish, but did have several very large individuals, likely lingcod.





Figure 2: Distributions of fish size by site
